feed.title: Jaron J.C. Maene
feed.subtitle: A blog about technology and stuff related

entry.title: What’s the complexity of Fibonacci?
entry.content:
The fibonacci series is so well-known, that introducing it almost seems redundant. But for good measure:

Fn=Fn−1+Fn−2F_n = F_{n-1} + F_{n-2}Fn​=Fn−1​+Fn−2​

With initial elements F0=0F_0 = 0F0​=0 and F1=1F_1 = 1F1​=1.1 Implementing the fibonacci function seems very simple. It’s usually the second thing I try out when learning new language, right after "Hello world!". However, few know that this is a much deeper problem than it appears to be on the surface. In this article, we’ll dive into the question of what the fastest algorithm for calculating fibonacci numbers could be, and what its complexity is.

I encourage you to reflect on the question for a few minutes on your own, before reading the rest of this article. You may suprised to find that a quick google (at time of writing) will not help you! Wikipedia does not contain the result, and almost all of the fora/blogs to pop up on the first google page have erronous/lacking answers.

Naive solution

Let’s start of our quest with the most basic algorithm:

def fib1(n):
    if n==0 or n==1:
        return n
    return fib1(n-1) + fib1(n-2)

This solution is very elegant, but not very efficient. How inefficient you say? Well recursion often makes it hard to see the exact time complexity. What you can see, is the recurrence relation:

T(n)=T(n−1)+T(n−2)+O(1)T(n) = T(n-1) + T(n-2) + O(1) T(n)=T(n−1)+T(n−2)+O(1)

Notice how this is almost the same recurence relation as the fibonacci series itself! With a little work you can confirm this intuition by showing that T(n)=O(Fn)T(n) = O(F_n)T(n)=O(Fn​). As will be discussed later, fibonacci is roughly exponential (to be exact: O(Fn)=O(ϕn)O(F_n) = O(\phi ^ n)O(Fn​)=O(ϕn)), confirming that this is pretty horrible implementation speed-wise.

Linear time

A more sensible approach would be to use an imperative loop instead of recursion.

def fib2(n):
    acc1 = 0
    acc2 = 1
    for i in range(n):
        acc1, acc2 = acc2, acc1+acc2
    return acc1

Another way of seeing this, is that we are applying dynamic programming: the last 2 results are memoised.

You can also get the same affect by staying functional, and using accumulators instead of local variables.

def fib3(n):
    # Defining auxiliary functions inside the main 
    # function avoids polluting the global namespace.
    def fib_aux(n, acc1, acc2):
        if n==0:
            return acc1
        return fib_aux(n-1,acc2,acc1+acc2)
    
    return fib_aux(n, 0, 1)

It should be clear that both fib2 and fib3 are of linear time complexity, a great improvement on fib1. In practice fib3 will be slower than fib2, as Python does not have tail-recursion, fib3 creates an extra stack frame each loop. In other words, the memory usage of fib3 will be linear, while fib2 has constant usage. Note that other languages (notably functional ones) do optimize tail-call recursion. In these languages fib2 and fib3 should be practically the same when compiled.

Sublinear time

Usually, discussion on fibonacci stops here. Maybe because it was just an example to explain dynamic programming. Or maybe because linear complexity suffices for their usecase. But could it be possible to do better than this?

It has long been known that there is a exact formula for the fibonacci sequence:

F[n]=ϕn−(1−ϕ)n5 F[n] = \frac{\phi^n - (1-\phi)^n}{\sqrt{5}}F[n]=5​ϕn−(1−ϕ)n​

Where ϕ\phiϕ is the golden ratio. This is known as Binet’s formula (altough Binet wasn’t the first to invent it, at least two others did before him). How to derive this isn’t super relevant here, but it’s discussed briefly in the appendix if you’re interested.

This should be easy to implement in python:

def sqrt(n): 
    return n**.5
phi = (1 + sqrt(5)) / 2

def fib4(n):
    return (phi**n - (1-phi)**n) / sqrt(5)

Alas, we forgot an important detail. Computers work in finite precision. For large nnn, the rounding errors can become very big. This means fib4 is only usable to get an approximation of the result, which is not what we’re interested in. There are ways to fix this (see appendix), but their performance is usually not great either. Seems like we’ll need to try out something else…

Let’s back up and review how the fib3 works. (It is often easier to reason mathematically on functional code). At each call the function has the parameters (n, FnF_nFn​, Fn+1F_{n+1}Fn+1​). All the auxillary function does is turn (n, FnF_nFn​, Fn+1F_{n+1}Fn+1​) to (n, Fn+1F_{n+1}Fn+1​, Fn+Fn+1F_n + F_{n+1}Fn​+Fn+1​). We can reframe this to the following matrix notation:

(F[n+2]F[n+1])=(1110)⋅(F[n+1]F[n]) \begin{pmatrix} F[n+2] \\ F[n+1] \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{pmatrix} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} F[n+1] \\ F[n] \\ \end{pmatrix} (F[n+2]F[n+1]​)=(11​10​)⋅(F[n+1]F[n]​)

This is a sensible thing to do for 2 reasons. First of all, by framing the problem in a linear algebra background, we may be able to use prior background knowledge we have in this field. Secondly, this removes the annoying part where the next state relies on the previous 2 states. Here, it is possible to calulate the next term, just using the last vector.

Because of this last fact, it is easy to obtain a closed formula:

(F[n+1]F[n])=(1110)n⋅(F[1]F[0]) \begin{pmatrix} F[n+1] \\ F[n] \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{pmatrix}^{n} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} F[1] \\ F[0] \\ \end{pmatrix} (F[n+1]F[n]​)=(11​10​)n⋅(F[1]F[0]​)

After filling in the initial conditions, you can show that:

(1110)n=(Fn+1FnFnFn−1) \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{pmatrix}^{n} = \begin{pmatrix} F_{n+1} & F_{n} \\ F_n & F_{n-1} \\ \end{pmatrix} (11​10​)n=(Fn+1​Fn​​Fn​Fn−1​​)

So now our problem is reduced to quickly computing (1110)n \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{pmatrix}^{n} (11​10​)n.

Doing this the naive way, reduces to same algoritm of fib2. But you can speed up exponentation by taking advantage of the fact that x2n=xn⋅xn x^{2n} = x^n \cdot x^n x2n=xn⋅xn instead of using the naive xn+1=x⋅xn x^{n+1} = x \cdot x^n xn+1=x⋅xn.

Note that this an application of the divide and conquer strategy. What a follows is a simple python implementation of this idea:

# we represent the matrix as a 4-tuple:
X = (1, 1, 1, 0)

# multiplication of matrices
def mult_matrix(A,B):
    (a,b,c,d) = A
    (e,f,g,h) = B
    u = a*e + b*g
    w = a*f + b*h
    x = c*e + d*g
    y = c*f + d*h
    return (u,w,x,y)


def fib5(n):
        
    def fib5b(n):
        # Returns X^n
        if n==0:
            return (1,0,0,1)
        elif n%2==1:
            return mult_matrix(X,fib5b(n-1))
        else:
            A = fib5b(n//2)
            return mult_matrix(A,A)
        
    return fib5b(n)[1]

We can further shave of some computations by extracting exact formulas from the matrix algorithm. Start by using the halving trick:

(1110)2n=((1110)n)2 \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{pmatrix}^{2n} = \left(\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \\ \end{pmatrix}^n\right)^2 (11​10​)2n=((11​10​)n)2

(F2n+1F2nF2nF2n−1)=(Fn+1FnFnFn−1)2 \begin{pmatrix} F_{2n+1} & F_{2n} \\ F_{2n} & F_{2n-1} \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} F_{n+1} & F_n \\ F_n & F_{n-1} \\ \end{pmatrix}^2 (F2n+1​F2n​​F2n​F2n−1​​)=(Fn+1​Fn​​Fn​Fn−1​​)2

(F2n+1F2nF2nF2n−1)=(Fn+12+Fn2Fn(Fn−1+Fn+1)Fn(Fn−1+Fn+1)Fn2+Fn−12) \begin{pmatrix} F_{2n+1} & F_{2n} \\ F_{2n} & F_{2n-1} \\ \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} F_{n+1}^2 + F_n^2 & F_n (F_{n-1} + F_{n+1}) \\ F_n (F_{n-1} + F_{n+1}) & F_{n}^2 + F_{n-1}^2 \\ \end{pmatrix} (F2n+1​F2n​​F2n​F2n−1​​)=(Fn+12​+Fn2​Fn​(Fn−1​+Fn+1​)​Fn​(Fn−1​+Fn+1​)Fn2​+Fn−12​​)

Now we have exact formulas for the even and odd case!

F2n=Fn(Fn−1+Fn+1)=Fn(2Fn+1−Fn) F_{2n} = F_n (F_{n-1} + F_{n+1}) = F_n (2F_{n+1} - F_n) F2n​=Fn​(Fn−1​+Fn+1​)=Fn​(2Fn+1​−Fn​) F2n+1=Fn+12+Fn2 F_{2n+1} = F_{n+1}^2 + F_n^2 F2n+1​=Fn+12​+Fn2​

We can condense these ideas in the following (fairly elegant) algorithm:

def fib6(n):
    if n < 2:
        return n

    a, b = 1, 1
    # [3:] because first 2 digits are "0b" + to skip first iteration
    for bit in bin(n)[3:]:
        a, b = a*(2*b - a) , a*a + b*b
        # in the odd case add a single fib iteration
        if bit == '1':
            a, b = b, a+b
    return a

The time complexity of the above function is linear in the amount of digits, so O(log(n))O(log(n))O(log(n)). A significant improvement on fib2!

The above algorithm is similar to what is used in actual high-performance code, such as the legendary GMP. Altough they do apply a little further optimisation. For example, the above version uses 3 multiplications in each call, but it is possible to use only 2. (Note that the 2*b is not counted as a multiplication, as it’s done with bit shifting in practice).

Warning, lots of math ahead. You can skip to the next section.

It’s already know that:
F2n=Fn(2Fn+1−Fn) F_{2n} = F_n (2F_{n+1} - F_n) F2n​=Fn​(2Fn+1​−Fn​) F2n+1=Fn+12+Fn2 F_{2n+1} = F_{n+1}^2 + F_n^2 F2n+1​=Fn+12​+Fn2​

The second formula is straightforward, but the first one is a bit more akward. It would be easier if it was also expressed in terms of Fn+12F_{n+1}^2Fn+12​ and Fn2F_n^2Fn2​. Rearranging the above formula:

F2n=2FnFn+1−Fn2 F_{2n} = 2F_n F_{n+1} - F_n^2 F2n​=2Fn​Fn+1​−Fn2​

Fn2F_n^2Fn2​ is already here, we can get Fn+12F_{n+1}^2Fn+12​ by doing:

F2n=2(Fn+1−Fn−1)Fn+1−Fn2 F_{2n} = 2(F_{n+1} - F_{n-1}) F_{n+1} - F_n^2 F2n​=2(Fn+1​−Fn−1​)Fn+1​−Fn2​ F2n=2Fn+12−Fn2−2Fn−1Fn+1 F_{2n} = 2F_{n+1}^2 - F_n^2 - 2F_{n-1} F_{n+1} F2n​=2Fn+12​−Fn2​−2Fn−1​Fn+1​

Now the remaining problem is getting rid of the Fn−1Fn+1F_{n-1} F_{n+1}Fn−1​Fn+1​ term. The trick to doing this is realising that:

∣Fn+1FnFnFn−1∣=Fn+1Fn−1−Fn2 \begin{vmatrix} F_{n+1} & F_{n} \\ F_n & F_{n-1} \end{vmatrix} = F_{n+1} F_{n-1} - F_{n}^2 ∣∣∣∣∣​Fn+1​Fn​​Fn​Fn−1​​∣∣∣∣∣​=Fn+1​Fn−1​−Fn2​

∣Fn+1FnFnFn−1∣=∣1110∣n=(−1)n \begin{vmatrix} F_{n+1} & F_{n} \\ F_n & F_{n-1} \end{vmatrix} = \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{vmatrix}^n = (-1)^n ∣∣∣∣∣​Fn+1​Fn​​Fn​Fn−1​​∣∣∣∣∣​=∣∣∣∣∣​11​10​∣∣∣∣∣​n=(−1)n

Implying that Fn−1Fn+1+Fn2=(−1)nF_{n-1}F_{n+1} + F_n^2 = (-1)^nFn−1​Fn+1​+Fn2​=(−1)n. This is known as Cassini’s identity.

Using this, we arrive at:
F2n=2Fn+12−3Fn2−2(−1)n F_{2n} = 2F_{n+1}^2 - 3F_n^2 - 2(-1)^n F2n​=2Fn+12​−3Fn2​−2(−1)n F2n+1=Fn+12+Fn2 F_{2n+1} = F_{n+1}^2 + F_n^2 F2n+1​=Fn+12​+Fn2​

Clearly evaluating these relations needs only two squares, an improvement on the previous 3 multiplications.

Evaluating

Thus far was all theory. Let’s plot some graphs to see if it actually worked.

Starting off with the first three implementations, remember that fib1 was the naive implementation with exponential time complexity, while fib2 and fib3 had linear complexity.

As to be expected, fib1’s runtime explodes, while the other 2 remain virtually constant. Now let’s see if the added complexity of fib5 and fib6 are worth it:

It was, fib2 is way slower. Note that fib3 is not included here. Because of the maximum recursion depth of python, it doesn’t work on input larger than 2000 (altough you can edit this barrier). Lastly, let’s review fib5 and fib6 on larger data:

Wait, didn’t I say that fib5/6 were O(log(n))O(log(n))O(log(n))? These do not look like logarithms at all, they appear to be superlinear! What’s going on?

Digging deeper

The flaw in our previous analysis, is the implicit assumption that addition and multiplication are O(1)O(1)O(1). This is case for 32-bit integers, as the operations are implemented in hardware. But unlike Java or C, which use i32 integers, python uses arbitrary size integers. This is obviously necessary to avoid overflows (F50F_{50}F50​ is enough to overflow in i32), but also costly: addition and multiplication no longer have constant time usage.

Addition for big integers is straightforward. It’s not unlike the grade school method, you have an array of i32’s and add them from right to left, taking the carries into account. As such the complexity is linear in the amount of digits, so O(log(n))O(log(n))O(log(n)). Multiplication fares worse, the naive algorithm is quadratic in the number of digits: O(log(n)2)O(log(n)^2)O(log(n)2).

Look at the last multiplication needed in fib6: Fn/2⋅Fn/2F_{n/2} \cdot F_{n/2}Fn/2​⋅Fn/2​ . This will have a time complexity of: O(log(Fn/2)2)=O(log(ϕn/2)2)=O(n2)O(log(F_{n/2})^2) = O(log(\phi^{n/2})^2) = O(n^2) O(log(Fn/2​)2)=O(log(ϕn/2)2)=O(n2). This is far greater than the constant time assumed! By applying the master’s theorem, the complexity of the entire algorithm becomes O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) instead of the assumed O(log(n))O(log(n))O(log(n)).

It was long assumed that O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) is the best possible algorithm for multiplication. Famously, the young Karatsuba didn’t believe his professor (another famous Russian computer scientist: Kolmogorov) who proclaimed this in a lecture. The result is the Karatsuba algorithm, which has complexity O(nlg(3))≈O(n1,58)O(n^{lg(3)}) \approx O(n^{1,58})O(nlg(3))≈O(n1,58), a considerable improvement. The algorithm is based on a divide an conquer approach, much like the Strassen algorithm for matrix multiplication. Further research has resulted in several algorithms which decreased the complexity further still. (Altough the ever increasing constant factors have limited practical usability). Some may find it suprising to hear, that multiplying 2 numbers is still an open research question. Just last March, a new algorithm was proposed2, that obtained the elusive limit of O(n⋅log(n))O(n \cdot log(n))O(n⋅log(n)). It has been long conjectured that this would be the best possible complexity, but no proof has been found yet.

Python is smart enough not to use the naive multiplication for large numbers. It uses the Karatsuba algorithm. So fib6 has time complexity O(n1,58)O(n^{1,58})O(n1,58) (which is finally the correct answer).

Finishing off

This was a deeper rabit hole than I had anticipated. The beauty is how much fibonacci brings together. We came across a lot of important CS concepts like dynammic programming, divide-and-conquer and floating point errors.

The final answer shows just how little we still know in computer science. Even for a simple problem like calculating the fibonacci numbers, the optimal complexity is unknown. (Altough O(nlog(n))O(nlog(n))O(nlog(n)) seems very likely.)

References

Some good further sources on this problem:

  • Blogpost by Oran Looney. Good article, digs into lots of the same things as here, altough it maybe doesn’t quite get as technical.
  • Fast fibonacci algorithm for FFT-based multiplication
  • Blogpost by Nayuki. Short and to the point overview of the most important algorithms.
  • Blogpost by Paul Hanking. Another excellent article. It takes an entire different approach, by using generating functions.
  • Algorithms for computing Fibonacci numbers quickly, by JL Holloway. Master thesis, Comparing a lot of different algorithms.
  • Algorithm used in GMP

Appendix 1: Derivation of Binet’s formula

We’ll derive the formula using difference equations, but there are many other approaches. The fibonacci equation is linear (meaning every term is of the form aF[n+b]aF[n+b]aF[n+b] or constant), and homogenous (no constant term). This makes it very easy to solve. A thorough explanation whould lead us to far, but basically one solves this by converting to the characteristic polynomial:
x2−x−1=0 x^2 - x - 1 = 0 x2−x−1=0 This is obtained by substituting F[n+c]F[n+c]F[n+c] by xcx^cxc. Now, we find the roots: x=1±52 x = \frac{1 \pm \sqrt 5}{2} x=21±5​​ One might recognize this as the golden ratio: ϕ=1+52\phi = \frac{1 + \sqrt 5}{2}ϕ=21+5​​ So x=ϕx = \phix=ϕ or 1−ϕ1-\phi1−ϕ.

Using this we can find the exact solution: F[n]=c1ϕn+c2(1−ϕ)n F[n] = c_1\phi^n + c_2(1-\phi)^n F[n]=c1​ϕn+c2​(1−ϕ)n To find the constants c1c_1c1​ and c2c_2c2​, we only need to fill in the initial conditions.

F[0]=0=c1ϕ0+c2(1−ϕ)0 F[0] = 0 = c_1\phi^0 + c_2(1-\phi)^0 F[0]=0=c1​ϕ0+c2​(1−ϕ)0 ⇔c1+c2=0 \Leftrightarrow c_1 + c_2 = 0 ⇔c1​+c2​=0 and F[1]=1=c1ϕ−c1(1−ϕ) F[1] = 1 = c_1\phi - c_1(1-\phi) F[1]=1=c1​ϕ−c1​(1−ϕ) ⇔1=c1(2ϕ−1) \Leftrightarrow 1 = c_1(2 \phi - 1) ⇔1=c1​(2ϕ−1) ⇒c1=15=−c2 \Rightarrow c_1 = \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} = -c_2 ⇒c1​=5​1​=−c2​

This brings us to the solution:

F[n]=ϕn−(1−ϕ)n5 F[n] = \frac{\phi^n - (1-\phi)^n}{\sqrt{5}}F[n]=5​ϕn−(1−ϕ)n​

Another way of deriving the formula is using the matrix representation. When a matrix is symmetrix (like in our case), you can compute the eigendecomposition and find the explicit formula from there. This is explored more in detail in this blogpost by Oran Looney.

On a sidenode, this connection holds in general, linear recurrence/difference relations are just other representations of matrices. As such, roots of the characteristic polynomial will be eigenvalues of the matrix.

Appendix 2: Calculation of Binet’s formula

The first thing you could try is using arbitrary-precision floating-point arithmetic (e.g. using MPFR). This is an easy solution to the problem, but sadly also a pretty slow one.

A much more clever method is working in an exact arithmetic. So you can represent a number a+bϕa + b\phia+bϕ as a tuple (a,b). This works as multiplying will again give you a number of this form, because ϕ2=1+ϕ\phi^2 = 1+\phiϕ2=1+ϕ. In mathematical jargon, we say that Q[ϕ]\mathbf{Q}[\phi]Q[ϕ] is closed under addition and multiplication (which is all we need to calculate ϕn+(1−ϕ)n\phi^n + (1-\phi)^nϕn+(1−ϕ)n). For an implementation of this idea (where I stole the idea), see here.

Note that, when you work out the above solution, the algorithm will be similar to the matrix solution. Indeed, you can similarly use the same divide-and-conquer exponentation, to get the same complexity. I suppose you could also extract the F2nF_{2n}F2n​ identities by following this route, but haven’t tried it out myself.

class GoldenRational:
    def __init__(self, a, b):
        self.r = a
        self.g = b
        
    def __add__(self, other):
        return GoldenRational(self.r+other.r, self.g+other.g)
    
    def __sub__(self, other):
        return GoldenRational(self.r-other.r, self.g-other.g)
    
    def __neg__(self):
        return GoldenRational(-self.r, -self.g)
    
    
    def __mul__(self, other):
        a, b = self.tuple()
        c, d = other.tuple()
        return GoldenRational(a*c + b*d, d*(a+b) + b*c)
    
    def __pow__(self, exp):
        assert type(exp)==int
        if exp == 0:
            return GoldenRational(1,0)
        
        if exp%2 == 1:
            return self * self**(exp-1)
        else:
            t = self**(exp//2)
            return t*t
    
    def __str__(self):
        return "{} + {}*phi".format(*self.tuple())
    
    def __repr__(self):
        return "GoldenRational({},{})".format(self.r, self.g)
        
    def tuple(self):
        return self.r, self.g
    
PHI = GoldenRational(0,1)
SQRT5 = GoldenRational(-1, 2)
ONE = GoldenRational(1,0)

def fib8(n):
    return -(PHI**n).r + ((ONE-PHI)**n).r

Footnotes

  1. Other choices are possible of course, e.g. F0=2F_0=2F0​=2 and F0=1F_0=1F0​=1 are known as the Lucas numbers. ↩

  2. Integer multiplication in time O(n log n), by David Harvey and Joris van der Hoeven ↩
entry.summary: The fibonacci series is so well-known, that introducing it almost seems redundant. But for good measure:

entry.title: :ramen: Indigo, minimalist jekyll theme
entry.content:
Example of project - Indigo Minimalist Jekyll Template - Demo. This is a simple and minimalist template for Jekyll for those who likes to eat noodles.

What has inside?

  • Gulp
  • BrowserSync
  • Stylus
  • SVG
  • Travis
  • No JS
  • 98/100

Check it out here. If you need some help, just tell me.
